abstract: Federal research study published in journal Pediatrics finds human papillomavirus vaccine in use for last 10 years has decreased virus's presence in teenage girls by two-thirds; study advocates appeal to American doctors for broader acceptance of giving vaccine for HPV, which is sexually transmitted and linked to cervical cancer, to male and female teens.
lead_paragraph: A vaccine for human papillomavirus, which causes cervical cancer, has reduced its prevalence in teenage girls by almost two-thirds, the study said.

headline.main: HPV Sharply Reduced in Teenage Girls Following Vaccine, Study Says
headline.print_headline: Vaccine Has Reduced HPV in Teenage Girls by Almost Two-Thirds, Study Says

snippet: A vaccine for human papillomavirus, which causes cervical cancer, has reduced its prevalence in teenage girls by almost two-thirds, the study said.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
